meanings.definition: To choke or constrict (someone) so as to cause death.
meanings.sent1: The villain tried to strangulate the hero with a rope.
meanings.sent2: The python will strangulate its prey before swallowing it whole.
meanings.sent3: The clumsy magician accidentally tried to strangulate himself with his own scarf.
meanings.sent4: The darkness seemed to strangulate the room, making it hard to breathe.
meanings.sent5: The silence in the haunted house seemed to strangulate all sound.

meanings.sent1: She used a rubber band to strangulate the stack of papers together.
meanings.sent2: The boa constrictor will strangulate its prey before eating it.
meanings.sent3: The tight jeans seemed to strangulate her waist, making her uncomfortable.
meanings.sent4: The traffic jam seemed to strangulate the flow of cars on the highway.
meanings.sent5: The vines seemed to strangulate the tree, slowly taking over its branches.

meanings.definition: To cut off the oxygen supply to (a part of the body) by constricting a blood vessel.
meanings.sent1: The tight bandage accidentally began to strangulate the patient's arm.
meanings.sent2: The tourniquet was applied too tightly, threatening to strangulate the limb.
meanings.sent3: The overgrown ivy seemed to strangulate the fence, giving it a unique look.
meanings.sent4: The economic crisis seemed to strangulate the small businesses in the area.
meanings.sent5: The anxiety seemed to strangulate her thoughts, making it hard to focus.
